Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.Scientists are testing substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine how it enters mammalian cells in a culture. The cells maintain a <math alttext="120 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>120 millimolar (mM)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> intracellular concentration of substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The scientists determined the rate of entry of substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> into the cells at various external concentrations of substance <math alttext="L, open parenthesis, 10 through 100 millimolar, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L (10 to 100 mM)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in culture medium (Table 1).Table 1. (b) On the axes provided, construct an appropriately labeled line graph with correct scale and units to illustrate the data in Table 1.

(c) Determine the external concentration of substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that will result in one-half of the maximal entry rate.

(d) Predict the likely effect on the ability of substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to enter the cells if substance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is attached to a large protein instead of free in the culture.
